Fast forward to "Wicked: For Good. Set one year later, Nessarose is Munchkinland's newest governor, a dark, controlling workaholic who learns Boq, her true love, has actually been pining for Glinda (Grande) the entire time.
It's this betrayal that sets Nessarose up as one of the sequel's villains — a label Bode says is largely undeserved.

"I think Nessa is totally misunderstood. I think sometimes people can mix the bigger picture and just write her off as the villain or inherently evil," Bode says. "But I think the point of the film is to really show that all of these characters really have so many layers."
In "Wicked: For Good," Nessarose transforms from a happy, young girl to an isolated, cold woman — a metamorphosis Bode calls “devastating.”
“Even the whole dance scene, I think that hit close to home, because I do have other disabled friends where something similar has happened,” Bode explains.

“Where people are friends with them from a distance or they are asked out, but it’s only for a photo op or something to make the other person feel good type of thing, rather than really caring about them and discarding them when they’re no longer either useful or can benefit them,” Bode says.
Instead of being immoral, Nessarose is simply a product of her circumstances, Bode says.

"It's her just desperately wanting to hang on to the parts that she feels are good in her life. Wanting to really, so deeply, hold onto the moment of her at the dance, which was one of the happiest nights of her life really," she says of her character.

“Then when she finds out that all of it wasn’t true and, in addition to being abandoned by her sister — or at least that’s how she feels — and really having nobody left at the end of the day, I think there’s moments of her being like, ‘Well, I have nothing else to lose,’” she says.
Nessarose and her estranged sister do briefly reunite after the ousted witch returns to Munchkinland seeking to drum up support for her campaign to restore animals' rights.

After Nessarose confronts Elphaba for her perceived abandonment, she attempts to help Nessarose reunite with Boq. In the process, she makes Nessarose fly, restoring her child-like joy, if only for a brief moment.
The pivotal scene is symbolic in more ways than one.

“I think with a song like ‘Defying Gravity,’ where one of the lyrics is, ‘Everyone deserves a chance to fly,’ to me, that’s not just physically flying, it’s also metaphorically and feeling like you’re on top of the world or feeling like you do finally have control of your life in some way and flying on that high,” Bode says.
As for how that felt to film?

“I physically had fun flying in the air. What was most tricky for me was pretending like I wasn’t,” Bode recalls. “I do laugh in it, but going from that and then bringing it back down after, I think was the trick for sure.”
But when she shows Boq that she can fly, he tells her she no longer needs him. He asks if he can leave and profess his love for Glinda.

"When Boq sees Nessa flying, there's a real clear connection between her and Elphaba in that way," Slater tells TODAY.com. "I think, yes, it's magic, but it's also the kind of power that Elphaba has to fly. So I think that, in some ways, informs where the fear goes."

Nessarose reacts by trying to force him to love her — through magic. She attempts to cast a love spell using Elphaba's Grimmerie, but it results in Boq's heart shrinking. To save his life, Elphaba turns him into the Tin Man of "The Wizard of Oz" lore.
The physical transformation into the Tin Man took Slater up to five hours. But Slater suggests Boq remains more similar than different.

"I think it was really important to me that Boq, pre-transformation, is the same Boq, post-transformation. From his point of view, the world around him is changing, and he's just responding to it," Slater says.
Nessarose and Boq both meet tragic fates in "Wicked." Boq loses his humanity, while Nessa dies after Madame Morrible brings a tornado (yes, that tornado) to Oz, resulting in a house falling on her.
But the characters' actors are looking to the future. Slater is set to star in the play "Marcel on the Train," which opens on Broadway Feb. 22.
Bode says she's grateful for the opportunity she's had to be part of something so epic, but at the same time, is ready to move on.
"I think I'm just someone that can't have the same scenery for too long," she explains. "I love playing around and wearing a number of different hats, so I'm looking forward to the future."

title: Donald Glover Reveals He Suffered a Stroke During Childish Gambino Concert Tour
summary: Donald Glover revealed he suffered a stroke last year during a concert tour as his musical alter ego Childish Gambino."I had a really bad pain in my head in Louisiana and I did the show anyway," Glover, 42, told a concert crowd during a Nov. 22 performance at the musical festival Camp Flog Gnaw, per videos shared on social media
story: Donald Glover revealed he suffered a stroke last year during a concert tour as his musical alter ego Childish Gambino.

"I had a really bad pain in my head in Louisiana and I did the show anyway," Glover, 42, told a concert crowd during a Nov. 22 performance at the musical festival Camp Flog Gnaw, per videos shared on social media.
After the tour moved to Houston, he said he went to a hospital.
"The doctor was like, ‘You had a stroke,'" he said.
"The first thing I thought was like, 'Oh, here I am still copying Jamie Foxx,'" he joked, referring to the stroke the "Ray" star suffered in April 2023 that left him hospitalized for weeks.
"That’s really like the second thing. The first thing was like, 'I'm letting everybody down,'" Glover continued.
He said doctors went on to find "a hole in my heart," leading to him having two surgeries.
He then reflected on what his health scare has taught him while speaking with the crowd.

"They say everybody has two lives and the second life starts when you realize you have one. You've got one life, guys and I gotta be honest. The life I've lived with you guys has been such a blessing. I love seeing and performing for you guys," he said. "As my wife says, which I love, she says, if this life is a flavor, soon as I'm done give me another scoop."
"You should be living your life how you want because it can only get better," Glover concluded. "If we have to do this again, it can only get better.”
Glover's health update comes a little more than a year after he announced on Oct. 4, 2024, that he was canceling the remainder of Childish Gambino's "New World Tour" because of health issues.
The musician and actor revealed on X at the time that he had been hospitalized after dealing with an unspecified illness after a concert in New Orleans.
"As of now," he wrote, "I have surgery scheduled and I need time out to heal."

title: How Much Time Passed Between 'Wicked' and 'Wicked: For Good'? It's Less Than You Think
summary: How much time has passed before "Wicked: For Good"? The film's screenwriters unpack the time jump with TODAY.com.
story: The film adaptation of "Wicked" ends right when Act I of the hit Broadway musical does: with Cynthia Erivo's Elphaba deciding to turn against the Wonderful Wizard of Oz and fly from the Emerald City — all while belting out "Defying Gravity."
But where does its sequel, "Wicked: For Good," pick up?

The second film opens with the construction of the yellow brick road — yes, the one from 1939's "The Wizard of Oz" — which is carried out through the labor of the land's animals. But the work is interrupted by none other than Elphaba, who flies in on her broom to free the animals. Her rebellion is painted by the leaders in the Emerald City as pure violence, earning her the famous moniker the Wicked Witch of the West.

Meanwhile, after choosing not to leave Oz with her best friend at the end of the first film, Glinda has firmly established herself as a figurehead in "Wicked: For Good," opposing evil and raising Ozians' spirits.

Winnie Holzman, who wrote the book for "Wicked" and co-wrote both films, tells TODAY.com that just one year has passed since the end of "Wicked" and that fateful day in the Emerald City when Elphaba and Glinda chose their paths.

"That's why we say, the 12 turnings of the tide — I don't know if you could hear (Michelle Yeoh's Madame Morrible) say that — but she said, 'It has been 12 tide turns,'" Holzman says. "We were trying to find a way to say it that didn't sound just like our world."
Holzman says the goal was to subtly tell audiences that a "substantial amount of time" has passed, but not "an endless amount."
"It has to be that amount of time where a lot has happened, but Elphaba could start to feel discouraged. If it was three months, you know, she would be in a different headspace," she says.
Holzman's co-writer, Dana Fox, adds they also wanted to establish a feeling of "nostalgia."
"We wanted it to feel like that nostalgia of looking back at your youth that we could actually unearth that feeling in people," Fox says.

"A year felt like exactly the right amount of time. You know how it is when you've had a big year where so much has changed in your life — that's this year," she adds. "So it feels bigger than what it is but it's a year."
They also decided to make it a year to connect with the audience, which was introduced to the film world of "Wicked" this time last year.
"That will be what the audience's experience was because they saw the year ago," Fox says. "So we wanted them to come along with the girls in that way."
"But I purposefully didn't want it to say 'one year,'" Holzman adds.  "I mean that's so not Oz."
As for how they settled on "tide turns" as a unit of measure?
"Jon (M. Chu) has so much beautiful water imagery in both movies," Holzman says. "Water is such a symbol of the unconscious, of the dream-like state, where you go deeper and you analyze."
Plus (slight spoiler alert): Water is ultimately what "kills" Elphaba, as established in the "Wizard of Oz," Fox points out.
"It's also very feminine," she says.
Holzman and Fox say they considered all of these meanings as they wrote the script — even for just those two words.
"We're going deep, because these kind of things, even though the audience might go, 'Well I didn't make all those connections' — you don't have to, but they're in there somewhere," Holzman says.
"And we wanted to create a movie where if you watched it 20 times, you could get something new each time you watched it," Fox adds.

title: Jonathan Bailey and Jeff Goldblum Talk 'Wicked: For Good' — and You're Going to Laugh
summary: Actors Jonathan Bailey and Jeff Goldblum pair up to talk all things "Wicked: For Good," including the ending and the fate of the Wizard, Elphaba and Fiyero.
story: Warning: This article contains major spoilers for "Wicked" and "Wicked: For Good."
The bromance between Jonathan Bailey and Jeff Goldblum is the real deal.

In fact, it's probably best that the co-stars share just about one scene between "Wicked" and "Wicked: For Good" because, like a couple of kids who need to be separated in class, nothing's going to get accomplished as long as they're in the same room.
"I'm the Robin to his Batman," Bailey says of Goldblum to TODAY.com.
"I'm the Cher to his Sonny," Goldblum replies.
Between the two, they're a veritable powerhouse of talent.

Goldblum has been a staple of the big screen starting from his memorable one-liner in “Annie Hall” back in 1977, to appearing in blockbuster films like "Independence Day," "The Grand Budapest Hotel" and "Jurassic Park."
Bailey began his career as a stage actor before making headlines as a royal in the Netflix hit "Bridgerton," as well as earning an Emmy nod for his 2023 turn in the series "Fellow Travelers."
Most recently, Bailey joined Goldblum in becoming a "Jurassic Park" alum after starring in "Jurassic World Rebirth" last summer.

Playing the Wizard of Oz and Prince Fiyero, respectively, Goldblum and Bailey have been traveling the globe for the past couple of weeks promoting "Wicked: For Good," the sequel to last year's box office smash "Wicked," starring Cynthia Erivo as Elphaba and Ariana Grande as Glinda.

During what Bailey and Goldblum mourn as their final joint interview of the "Wicked: For Good" press tour, the two friends banter, ponder plot points (spoilers ahead!) and discuss why the film is exactly the right movie at the right time.
This interview has been lightly edited for clarity.
Jonathan Bailey: We were just talking about that.
Jeff Goldblum: We were just talking about that because ...
JB: He lands in the opening sequence of his spinoff (laughing).

JG: The Gregory Maguire books, I think there are seven of them, I think there's a lot of material that probably answers a lot of questions. I was just asking (Maguire) about what happens to Fiyero ... what is that nothingness place? I think it's described in some of those books. What are they going to do?
You saw the movie? Did you get the idea that (Fiyero) is now eternal? Lives forever as a straw person? I have to see it many more times.
JB: (Elphaba and Fiyero) have a family.
JG: They have children ... you were saying. In the books, they have children.
JB: Yes.
JG: There are a bunch of books. And Frank Baum (author of "The Wizard of Oz") wrote a bunch of books at the beginning of the 1900s, so there's material galore.
JB: I just want a film called "Wizard" with Jeff (laughing). But you would play every part like "Big Momma’s House."
JG: I’d like to see "Momma’s House." Or, I'd like to see Fiyero and Elphaba in the "Dunescape."
JB: We'll call it ... "Making Hay." (Laughing)
JG: "Making Hay," excellent. (Laughing)
JB: Making hay, all day and night. (Laughing)
JG: I think, it's very serious. It's like "Scenes From a Marriage," and we cover the next 20 years of their relationship.

JB: It was all prosthetics. There’s no CGI, there’s no special effects. It’s an extraordinary thing to be in any sort of film that celebrates the creative arts in the way that (“Wicked”) does and I think everyone’s been able to flex years of craft.

It was four-and-a-half hours every morning. It was Mark (Coulier), who’s an extraordinary designer, who came up with this burlap texture and it was the first conversation I had with Frances (Hannon), to think about where the literal transformation ends.
There's so much that we sort of explored, the physicality, obviously with a nod to Ray Bolger (the original Scarecrow in "The Wizard of Oz").

There's footage of a camera test which made me ... I kind of started crying because it was so reminiscent of "The Wizard of Oz," and it was me and Ethan (Slater) as the Tin Man and Bethany Weaver as Dorothy.
They had a chalk slate and we just walked up and down the yellow brick road and we were just exploring the characters. That was almost one of my highlights, actually.

JG: I'd like to see that. There are many things about the ending that intrigue me now. What's the nothingness like? What happens to them? You know, Boq, that's very interesting and savage, his whole thing, it fascinates me. But the two ladies, our main story, wooooow!
JB: The Grimmerie really comes alive.

JG: And does Elphaba now not have the powers that she did with the Grimmerie? And why couldn't she have trusted (Glinda) perhaps? There's a lovely line, "I have to be wicked so you can be good." Glinda is amazing, why couldn't (Elphaba) trust that, "Hey, we're going to be OK. Don't try to contact us, etc., etc.. Don't tell anybody that we faked it."

Or, or is the loss that Glinda experiences the portal, the thing that triggers her power, her ability to go through that loss of the greatest love that she's ever had, really, with Elphaba? Does that trigger her ability to that power?
JB: I think what's going to happen is "Dune" Part 3 is coming out in cinemas next year, and I think Fiyero and Elphaba are just going to walk into the shot ...
JG: (Both laughing) And you'll go, "People ... "
JB: "Timmy?
JG: "Timothee Chalamet?"
JB: I think the answers always lie in the Grimmerie.

I do think it's particularly thrilling to see the Grimmerie come alive and for someone — Ariana (Grande) charts so brilliantly — is that the absolute knowledge that (Glinda) has no magic and she no power. To see the Grimmerie come alive, feels to me, like a transference and a conversation between the two women.
JG: Certainly, Elphaba telepathically kind of does that as they commune with each other across the space.

Does Glinda? ... Good question. Does Glinda go, "I don't think I did that. Are you out there somewhere?" Maybe it's meant to be ambiguous. Ask Jon M. Chu this question because every moment means something and he, I'm sure, intends and has excavated all the logic behind all of that.
JB: As we know with grief, as well, is that these people do always exist in a different form, don't they? So, in a metaphysical sense, they are still living on together.
JG: Yes, you've changed me for good, meaning both those things, of course, forever.
JB: There's so much hope and optimism in this story and that lies with seeing other sides and being curious about other perspectives. And what a time to be celebrating that idea.
JG: Empathy. Empathy. A valuable commodity, now more than ever. If this movie isn't a machinery for the spread of empathy, I don't know what is.
JB: And it just takes one person. It can be one act of kindness. It can have a ripple effect and one intentional act of radicalism that can inspire and shift.
JG: The pebble in the lake and the spreading rings.

title: How Michelle Yeoh Made Her ‘Wicked’ Character Terrifying — Without Ever Raising Her Voice
summary: Oscar-winning actor, Michelle Yeoh, talks "Wicked: For Good," what it took to transform into Madame Morrible and the "sisterhood" she shares with her co-stars.
story: Warning: Spoilers ahead for "Wicked" and "Wicked: For Good."
According to Michelle Yeoh, the real witches in "Wicked" aren't the ones you immediately think of. And she'd know, because she's one of them.
"There were only two witches in the Land of Oz," Yeoh tells TODAY.com in a sit-down interview. "It was Madame Morrible and Elphaba."

That may come as a surprise to fans of the "Wizard of Oz" who think that when it comes to "Wicked's" witches, that distinction belongs to the Wicked Witch of the West, Elphaba (Cynthia Erivo), and Glinda the Good Witch (Ariana Grande).
But to know the musical is to remember that the only two people with any sort of magical ability in Oz are, in fact, Elphaba and Morrible, not Glinda and definitely not The Wizard.
That's why Yeoh says her character, Madame Morrible, initially aligns herself with Elphaba, before ultimately becoming her biggest adversary.

"She didn't have quite the gift and talent as Elphaba did. But at that moment, she thought, 'I found my muse. I couldn't do it, but now I have someone who can help me get to where I think it's for the goodness of Oz,'" explains Yeoh of Madame Morrible's less-than-honorable intentions for the young sorcerer.

If that's not enough to convince you that Morrible is the true wicked witch of the story, consider her initials: "MM." Turn them upside down and what have you got? "WW," which stands for — you guessed it — Wicked Witch.

Without revealing too much, it's safe to say that Madame Morrible gets the ending she deserves in "Wicked: For Good." Even so, it's hard not to wonder if, in spite of her malicious intent, there's anything redeeming about the character.

"I think the lesson to be learned here is don't get corrupted by your own desires and ambition," says Yeoh. "Because (Madame Morrible) forgot about compassion and kindness, which is something she had right at the beginning. And then she got lost in her own tempest."
Bringing the 'Scary' to Madame Morrible

Fresh off the heels of her Oscar win for "Everything Everywhere All At Once" in 2023, Yeoh stepped into the shoes of the "Wicked" character. To portray Madame Morrible, Yeoh says she drew on past experience to give Shiz’s imposing headmistress her commanding presence.

"I think everything that I've done, especially in the physicality of my life, whether ... from ballet, to contemporary dance, to sports, to diving, to all these kind of things, helped me focus the stillness rather than the chaotic movement."
Instead of playing Morrible as an over-the-top villain, Yeoh says she took a more subtle approach and worked at curating Morrible's icy but alluring appeal.

"This is how she would command respect and awe. It's like, how does she charm them? She draws them in," explains Yeoh. "That's the most scary of all — when they're charming and personable and they listen to you and it seems like you're the only one in her world."
"With Madame Morrible, this was an art form that she needed to have to have that gravitas," she continues.
Morrible's high-collared costumes and elaborate up-dos also contributed to her intimidating stature, Yeoh says.
"It was the combination of everything that helped me build Madame Morrible to when she walks out, you go back and go, 'Alright, not going to mess with you!'"

It's not the first time Yeoh has used her inner stillness to bring a character to life. She says she also channeled it for her work in  "Memoirs of a Geisha" and the hit 2018 rom-com, "Crazy Rich Asians," which was also directed by Jon M. Chu.

"The mother, Mrs. Eleanor Young, is also a very commanding figure without being loud, she never raises her voice, but when she speaks with her tone, every gesture is measured with intention. It's not frivolous. It's nothing like that," Yeoh says.
"So, when she stops to look at you, you go, "Okayyyy," she adds.
Forging a Sisterhood

Based on the 1995 Gregory Maguire book, "Wicked: The Life and Times of the Wicked Witch of the West," bringing the films "Wicked" and "Wicked: For Good" to the big screen has been a decades-long endeavor that began back in the early 2000s.
Yeoh joined the cast in 2022 and filmed the original and sequel simultaneously along with the rest of the cast, including Ariana Grande and Cynthia Erivo.

"You will miss (them), because at the end of the day, you've built up such a great bond and it's a family," says Yeoh, who explains that while goodbyes can be hard, they're also an inevitable part of the business.

"This is how it is, but the good news is if you really bonded, they'll always be there. I'm still in touch with Jamie Lee Curtis, and it's been so many years. And 'Crazy Rich Asians,' we still have a group chat," she says.
As for Grande and Erivo, Yeoh says that even though the films are done, what she takes away from her co-stars is a lasting sisterhood.
"We champion each other. We believe in each other. We support each other. No questions asked, let's just go forward, up and above, let's just do it together," Yeoh says.
"And when we're not with each other, we don't forget that will always have the bond."

title: Olivia Dean Calls Out Ticketmaster, Live Nation, AEG for Ticket Pricing Controversy
summary: Olivia Dean is apologizing to her fans and calling out Ticketmaster, Live Nation and AEG Presents after the websites showed increased prices for her upcoming “The Art of Loving Live” tour.
story: Olivia Dean is apologizing to her fans and calling out Ticketmaster, Live Nation and AEG Presents after the websites showed increased prices for her upcoming “The Art of Loving Live” tour.

On Nov. 14, the British crooner announced her 2026 tour across the United States and Canada on Instagram, and shared that tickets would be available for pre-sale starting Nov. 18. But when her many passionate fans attempted to purchase tickets after waiting in a lengthy queue, they found that the prices, especially for resale tickets, had skyrocketed.
Many voiced their frustrations with price gouging on social media.
One fan on X posted a screenshot of pricing for a balcony level seat at Dean’s TD Garden show in Boston that appeared to cost $753.45 on Ticketmaster’s website.
Others posted videos revealing that some seats were immediately being resold for prices as high as $992.16 after originally ranging from $140 to $180.
One exasperated person tweeted, “Getting Olivia Dean tickets feels impossible atp.”
In response to the first tweet, Ticketmaster said that the high price was due to a “typo.”

“Appreciate you flagging this,” the company replied to the X user. “The price was a typo, but has since been updated to the correct $53.45 all in price. Refunds for the difference have been automatically issued.”
The company also posted similar replies to other fans who shared screenshots of the pricing error.
TODAY.com reached out to Ticketmaster for additional comment.
When the general sale for the “Art of Loving” tour began on Friday, Nov. 21, Dean posted a statement on her Instagram story addressing the ticketing controversy.
“Hello world! I’m sorry that there seems to be an issue with ticket re-selling and pricing,” she wrote. “My team are currently looking into it.”
The “Man I Need” singer continued, “It is extremely frustrating as the last thing i want is for anyone to be scammed or overcharged for our show.”
She added a sad face emoticon and cautioned her fans to look out for scammers trying to sell them tickets.
In another Instagram story, she voiced her disapproval of how Ticketmaster, Live Nation and AEG Presents handled her concert sales, especially the resale tickets.
“@ticketmaster @livenation @aegpresents you are providing a disgusting service,” she said. “The prices at which you’re allowing tickets to be re-sold is vile and completely against our wishes.”
Dean said that live music should be “affordable and accessible” to fans and that the everyone should be working to make that happen.
“BE BETTER,” she wrote at the end of her post.
Ticketmaster replied to Dean on its Instagram story, writing, “We support artists’ ability to set the terms of how their tickets are sold and resold.”
The company added, “@oliviadeano, we will cap resale prices on our site at face value and hope other resale sites will follow.”
AEG Presents said in a statement to TODAY.com, "we have been vocal in our support of legislation that protects artists and fans alike.”

“As soon as we noticed the price irregularities in the secondary market, we immediately shut down resale for the one Olivia Dean show that was promoted by AEG Presents and ticketed by AXS," the company said in a statement.
TODAY.com has reached out to Live Nation for a comment.
Fans applauded Dean for sticking up for them on X.
“What a woman!” one complimented the Grammy nominee.
Another agreed, writing, “No one’s doing it like her.”
A third said, “And she should say it!!!! those tickets were barely 200 dollars and are being sold for thousands… what are we doing.”

title: 'RHOA' Star Kandi Burruss Splits From Husband Todd Tucker After 11 Years of Marriage
summary: "Real Housewives of Atlanta" star Kandi Burruss is separating from her husband, Todd Tucker, after 11 years of marriage.
story: "Real Housewives of Atlanta" star Kandi Burruss and her husband, Todd Tucker, are separating after 11 years of marriage.
Burruss revealed she was calling it quits from the producer in a statement to People.

“After deep thought and a lot of prayer, I’ve made the decision to move forward with a divorce," she said. "This is a difficult and emotional time, but my focus remains on protecting my peace, being the best mother I can be, and co-parenting with love and respect."

“I’m stepping into a new chapter pouring into my work, my family, and my own growth," she continued. "I’m grateful to everyone who supported us throughout the years, and I ask for privacy, grace, and understanding as we navigate this transition with our family."

Burruss and Tucker got married in 2014, and they share their two young kids, Ace and Blaze. The reality TV star is also a proud mom to a 23-year-old daughter, Riley, whom she shares with her ex Russell “Block” Spencer. Tucker has a 29-year-old daughter, Kaela, whom he welcomed with his ex Keema Parker.
Burruss and Tucker's divorce news comes one year after fans began speculating they were going their separate ways. But in an April 2024 interview with Us Weekly, Burruss shut down the rumors.

She explained that people might've thought that something was wrong in their marriage because of how passionately she and Tucker would argue with one another on camera when they would shoot content for their social media channels.

“We’re passionate when we go back and forth. I think people kind of mistook that to say we were angry with each other. But we’re (just) debating the topic," she said. "We’re going back and forth about this.”

“I’ve been like that my whole life. As soon as we have a back and forth, I can walk out the room and be like, ‘OK, now what are we doing next?’ Whereas I guess to somebody that’s watching it, they are thinking that it’s more than that," she added.
On April 4, 2025, Burruss celebrated her 11th wedding anniversary with Tucker by sharing a sweet photo montage of them through the years while her song "Me & U" played in the background.
"Wow! I can’t believe it’s been 11yrs of Me & You!  @todd167 I love you sooooooo much!" she penned the caption. "Let’s continue to love, grow, & glow up together. Happy anniversary babe!"

title: All the Differences Between ‘Wicked: For Good’ and Act II of the Musical
summary: Warning: This article contains spoilers for the stage musical “Wicked” and the movie “Wicked: For Good.”Like its predecessor, “Wicked: For Good” more than doubles the runtime of Act II of the Broadway musical that inspired it.
story: Warning: This article contains spoilers for the stage musical  “Wicked” and the movie “Wicked: For Good.”

Like its predecessor, “Wicked: For Good” more than doubles the runtime of Act II of the Broadway musical that inspired it. But unlike the first “Wicked” film, the sequel makes big additions to the storyline.
In addition to two brand new songs, “Wicked: For Good” adds a wedding, changes the composition of a pivotal song and makes a new casting connection to “The Wizard of Oz.”
Winnie Holzman, who wrote the book for “Wicked” and co-wrote “Wicked: For Good” with Dana Fox, says “we always knew we weren’t going to just plunk (Act II) into a movie script.”

“We wanted to make sure that it wasn’t Act II, that it was a full-blown, for real, movie with a wonderful beginning, middle and end,” Holzman says. “We weren’t going to change the story, but it had to do with really looking at every single moment of Act II and turning it into a movie.”
Overall, they say the biggest adjustment was developing Glinda’s arc after forging Elphaba’s in the first movie.

“We’re kind of following Glinda’s ups and downs in terms of, these are the consequences of her choices,” Fox says. “Elphaba made a choice and is standing by that choice. So in a way, she’s theoretically changing less, and she’s trying to change the world.
“Glinda is the one who needs some serious changing.”
Here are the most significant changes, additions and expansions found in “Wicked: For Good” compared to the original Broadway musical.
The Opening Scene

The stage musical of “Wicked” opens with a time jump from Elphaba’s rebellious moment in “Defying Gravity.” The first scene of Act II is “Thank Goodness,” sung by Glinda as she seeks to spread joy and raise spirits as the rest of Oz wages war against Elphaba, now dubbed the Wicked Witch of the West.

The movie also opens with a time jump — specifically one year. The first scene though, establishes the new reality in Oz. Animals are used as laborers to build the Wizard’s yellow brick road. It also reveals that since her dramatic departure from the Emerald City, Elphaba has been hijacking the work sites to try and free the animals.
The Animals Escape Oz
Speaking of the animals, “Wicked: For Good” also reveals the impact of the Wizard’s propaganda and laws forbidding animals from talking.

In a new scene, Elphaba comes across a group of animals escaping Oz via an underground route. They say they are searching for the mythical Lands Beyond Oz and tell a resistant Elphaba that the uncertainty is safer for them.
To try and persuade them to stay, Elphaba sings her new song, “No Place Like Home” — but to no avail.

“It’s this extraordinary anthem, and it doesn’t work,” Fox says. “The animals don’t stay because she can’t convince them, and the truth is they’re probably right to leave. At that moment they are doing what’s best for them, what is the safest choice for them.”
Elphaba's Spell Gives Nessarose the Ability to Fly
After failing to rally the animals to stay and fight with her, Elphaba goes to her sister, Nessarose (Marissa Bode), who’s now the governor of Munchkinland after the death of their father.

But Nessa, who has stripped munchkins of their right to travel in order to keep her love, Boq (Ethan Slater), by her side, is consumed by resentment. She yells at Elphaba for trying to help animals instead of her. As a result, Elphaba opens her Grimmerie and casts a spell on Nessarose, giving her the ability to fly.
Fans of the stage musical remember that in this scene, Elphaba’s spell gives Nessarose, who uses a wheelchair, the ability to walk.

Marissa Bode is the first actor to play Nessarose and use a wheelchair off-screen. She previously told TODAY that the change from walking to flying in “Wicked: For Good” represents “less of a case of my character wanting to be fixed, and more of her just taking in the magic itself.”
Glinda Performs ‘Wonderful’ With the Wizard
After trying to get her sister’s support, Elphaba goes directly to the Emerald City to try and take on the Wizard.
There, he again tries to get her to join forces with him via a song called “Wonderful.”
But in the film, Glinda joins the pair for the song. “Wonderful” becomes a duet between Glinda and the Wizard as they both try to convince Elphaba to return to the public’s good graces.
Glinda and Fiyero Almost Get Married
In the stage musical, Glinda and Fiyero are engaged before he ultimately abandons her to run off with Elphaba. In “Wicked: For Good,” they almost made it down the aisle.
When Elphaba goes to the Emerald City, it turns out to be on Glinda and Fiyero’s wedding day.

After Elphaba’s almost been convinced to join Glinda and the Wizard through their rendition of “Wonderful,” she asks the Wizard to free the flying monkeys she accidentally created in Part 1. He complies — but then she uncovers a secret crevice where the Wizard had kept in cages dozens of animals, including Elphaba’s former professor Dr. Dillamond, preventing them from speaking. Outraged, Elphaba frees all the animals, interrupting Glinda as she walks down the aisle.

“We wanted the stakes to be higher,” Chu says of the change. “We wanted to make this sort of intercut parallel between her getting married and (Elphaba’s) reality of finding these animals in cages. The fact that these two, dream and nightmare, could collide at this intersection was really important to break the story.”
When Fiyero, who’s captain of the guard, later finds Elphaba, he decides to escape with her, breaking Glinda’s heart.
Viewers See Dorothy — But Never Her Face

“The Wizard of Oz” and its characters are intertwined with “Wicked’s” story. For example, Boq and Fiyero famously become the Tin Man and the Scarecrow, while the cub that Fiyero and Elphaba rescue as students grows up to be the Cowardly Lion. But what about Dorothy?
In the stage musical, Dorothy is merely seen as a shadow throwing water on Elphaba in the film’s finale. But “Wicked: For Good” cast Bethany Weaver to play the part.
Throughout the film, viewers can see Dorothy, her brunette pigtails and her blue plaid dress, but only from the back. Her face is never seen.
That decision was easy, says Chu.

“There was a mantra that we were taught when we first started this from the people who did the stage show, and they said, ‘The key is it’s about the girls, stupid.’ ... That has guided our way the whole time,” he says.

“When it comes to Dorothy and all these other characters, those are really fun things, but in movie language, if you see her face, you’re going to want to know who she is, where she comes from, what does she want — and then the story takes a way left turn,” he adds. “And this is ‘about the girls, stupid.’”
Glinda Formally Takes Over as a Leader of Oz
After witnessing Fiyero’s capture and Madame Morrible’s cruelty, Glinda weighs whether to do something or stay complacent in the film’s second brand new song, “Girl in the Bubble.”

“Part of deconstructing the fairy tale — which is sort of the point of ‘Wicked,’ to see this American fairytale in a new way, through a new perspective — part of that was understanding not just what what Elphaba was going through, but also what it means for somebody in a bubble of privilege when the truth is coming out,” Chu says.

“At what point does someone who doesn’t have to be affected by this, what kind of courage does it take to actually pop your own bubble and engage and help somebody else? I think that that’s such an important lesson in these days, that courage — no matter where you missed the moment — courage has no expiration date, and that we still have time to be the people who we see ourselves as,” he adds.

She ultimately chooses to go to Elphaba’s side. The best friends briefly reconcile with “For Good” before Elphaba fakes her own death. After escaping, Glinda returns to the Emerald City, forces the departure of the Wizard, arrests Madame Morrible and takes over as a leader of Oz.
And in a slight expansion from the musical, we see exactly what she does with that newfound power: Free the animals.
The Grimmerie Opens for Glinda

Finally, the very end of “Wicked: For Good” introduces a scene that is meant to spark discourse. As Elphaba and Fiyero escape to the Lands Beyond Oz, Glinda looks out over the Emerald City. The magic book, the Grimmerie, which Elphaba entrusted to her before her “death,” suddenly comes alive and opens beside Glinda.

There are theories about what the Grimmerie’s opening means, even among the cast and crew. Some think it represents Glinda finally having the potential to be a true witch, while others say it’s a message from Elphaba to Glinda.
“What I think is great about this book of knowledge, the Grimmerie, I mean, it can be interpreted as many things,” Chu says.

title: What Did Ariana Grande Whisper to Cynthia Erivo at the End of 'Wicked: For Good?'
summary: "Wicked: For Good" is full of nods to the Broadway musical. But what did Ariana Grande whisper to Cynthia Erivo at the end? Here's what she told TODAY.com.
story: Warning: This article contains spoilers for the ending of "Wicked: For Good."
"Wicked: For Good" is full of references, Easter eggs and nods to the original Broadway musical that started it all — down to the very last shot.

After the heartbreaking duet "For Good," in which Elphaba and Glinda express their love for each other before forever parting, the final frame of the film re-creates one of the most iconic images associated with "Wicked": the original Playbill cover.
In the image, a woman with green skin smirks with her black witch's hat covering her eyes, while a woman dressed in all white whispers in her ear.

In the final frame of "Wicked: For Good," Elphaba (Cynthia Erivo) and Glinda (Ariana Grande) sit in a field. Glinda, wearing a knitted white shawl and head cover, leans over and whispers to Elphaba, who's of course wearing her signature black hat.

"That image is not in the show, it was just on a poster, and the poster becomes so iconic," Chu tells TODAY.com. "There's like, dissertations about that design, like, what are they saying? What does it mean? Is that friendship? Is that subversive? Is that a secret plan?
"I wanted to pay a nod to that, and have my own version of it," he adds.
In the final shot, Grande whispered to Erivo to re-create the image of the poster. But what exactly?
"I would never say," Erivo tells TODAY.com.
It's an example of a moment from the film that was "really intimate," she says.
"I think it's why this movie feels the way it feels, because there are so many really beautifully intimate, sweet, private moments that you end up watching on the screen," she says.
There is one person who knows what was said — at least, he thinks he does.

"I'm the only one who knows what the girls were saying to each other," Chu says. "And they may have been even lying to me, so I could see them definitely whispering something that's not what they said to me."
And then, the director adds: "And I will never reveal that. That's for sure."

title: What the 2 New Songs in 'Wicked: For Good' Reveal About Glinda and Elphaba
summary: The "Wicked: For Good" soundtrack is finally here, and with it comes the official cast recordings of two songs that are brand new to the musical.  Read the lyrics.
story: (Warning: Spoilers from "Wicked: For Good" below...)
The "Wicked: For Good" soundtrack is finally here, and with it comes the official cast recordings of two songs that are brand new to the musical.

"No Place Like Home," sung by Cynthia Erivo as Elphaba, and "The Girl in the Bubble," by Ariana Grande's Glinda, were written specifically for "Wicked's" sequel film — an addition director Jon M. Chu calls "really natural."
"We needed it in the story and how we wanted to really dive into each character," he says in an interview with TODAY.com.

Both songs were written by the original composer and lyricist for "Wicked," Stephen Schwartz, and both are ballads. In "No Place Like Home," Elphaba tries to get the animals to change their minds about fleeing Oz. Then later in the film, "The Girl in the Bubble" narrates Glinda's decision between taking a stand or remaining complicit in the Wizard (Jeff Goldblum) and Madame Morrible's (Michelle Yeoh) witch hunt of Elphaba.
Below, read the lyrics to "Wicked: For Good's" new songs and find out what each reveals about the film's leading ladies.
'No Place Like Home'

"No Place Like Home" is the third song in "Wicked: For Good" and it serves to establish what Elphaba's rebellion against the Wizard looks like in Oz. In addition to disrupting the construction of the Yellow Brick Road, she tries to prevent the animals, who are being captured and stripped of their rights, from leaving Oz, arguing in the film's chorus, "There's no place like home."

Erivo tells TODAY.com that she and Schwartz spoke about how to make those lines from "The Wizard of Oz" — which are repeated when Dorothy clicks the heels of her ruby slippers to try and leave Oz and return to Kansas — "make sense for Elphaba's story."
"If those are the words that I was going to say, 'No Place Like Home,' the iconic words, it had to count," Erivo says. "I had to make sure that saying them meant something."
Dana Fox, who co-wrote the screenplay of "Wicked: For Good" with Winnie Holzman, calls the song a "beautiful anthem."

"What's so powerful about it, weirdly, is first of all the idea that, how do you love a place that doesn't seem to love you back, feels so deep and profound right now," Fox says. "That's tough to watch right now."
And adding to that heartbreak, the "extraordinary anthem" doesn't work.

"The animals don't stay. She can't convince them," Fox explains. "The truth is they're probably right to leave. At that moment, they are doing what's best for them, what is the safest choice for them."
'No Place Like Home' Lyrics
Why do I love this place
That’s never loved me?
A place that seems to be devolving
And even wanting to?
But Oz is more than just a place
It’s a promise, an idea
And I want to help make it come true
Why should a land have so much meaning
When dark times befall it?
It’s only land, made of dirt and rock and loam
It’s just a place that’s familiar
And “home's” just what we call it
But there’s no place like home
Don’t we all know
There’s no place like home?
When you feel you can’t fight anymore
Just tell yoursеlf
There’s no place likе home
When you feel it’s not worth fighting for
Compel yourself
Because there’s no place like home
When you want to leave
Discouraged and resigned
That’s what they want you to do
But think how you will grieve
For all you leave behind
Oz belongs to you too
Those who would take it from you
Spout a lie to sell yourself
You go their way or go
It’s them we’ll be defeating
If we keep on repeating
“There’s no place like home”
There’s no place like home
There’s no place like home
If we just keep fighting for it
We will win back and restore it
There’s no place like home
'The Girl in the Bubble'
"The Girl in the Bubble" comes in toward the end of "Wicked: For Good."

The film opens with Glinda quite literally receiving her own powers of flight via a mechanical pink bubble, part of her status as the figurehead "Glinda the Good." She has been tasked with lifting Ozians' spirits amid the Wizard's campaign to paint Elphaba as a "Wicked Witch" terrorizing the land.

Throughout the film, Glinda's ability to trust the Wizard and Madame Morrible is tested. After her fiancé, Fiyero (Jonathan Bailey), and Elphaba run away together on Glinda's wedding day, she helps draw Elphaba out of hiding by targeting her sister, Nessarose (Marissa Bode).
But once Glinda realizes Madame Morrible was responsible for the twister that resulted in Nessarose's death, she's forced to look at her own complicity.

"The idea of 'The Girl in the Bubble' is really interesting because it could feel like a person talking about how they feel, or it could feel like a person making a decision," Fox says. "Where we had to make sure it landed was somewhere where it felt like it was motivating her to do something different, instead of just, 'Oh I'm sad I'm the girl in the bubble.'"
To do that, the writers "played around" with where exactly in the script the song would go.
"We played around with it actually even in post (production)," Fox reveals.
The song, and Glinda's decision in the end to "pop" her bubble, can represent the culmination of her character arc.

"Part of deconstructing the fairy tale, which is sort of the point of 'Wicked' ... part of that was understanding not just what Elphaba was going through, but also what it means for somebody in a bubble of privilege, when the truth is coming out and when people, the powerless, are going through things," Chu says. "At one point does someone who doesn't have to be affected by this, what kind of courage does it take to actually pop your own bubble and engage and help somebody else?"
'The Girl in the Bubble' Lyrics
Look, there’s that
Beautiful girl
With a beautiful life
Such a beautiful life
Built on lies
Cause all that’s required
To live in a dream
Is endlessly closing your eyes
She spins such beautiful stories
To sing her to sleep
Full of magic and glory and nerve
She’s the girl in the bubble
A bright shiny bubble
Blissfully floating above
Ah, but
The truth has a way
Of seeping on in
Beneath the surface and sheen
And blind as you’ve tried to be
Eventually
It’s hard to unsee what you’ve seen
And so that beautiful girl
With a beautiful life
Has a question that haunts her somehow
If she comes down from the sky
Gives the real world a try
Who in the world is she now?
And though so much of her wishes
That she could float on
And the beautiful lies never stop
For the girl in the bubble
The pink shiny bubble
It’s time for her bubble to pop
For the popular girl
High in the bubble
Isn’t it high time
For her bubble to pop

title: What Does ‘Wicked: For Good’s’ Final Scene Really Mean? Cynthia Erivo and More Explain It
summary: What does the opening of the Grimmerie mean at the end of "Wicked: For Good"? Jon M. Chu, Cynthia Erivo, Winnie Holzman and more explain.
story: Warning: This article contains spoilers for the ending of “Wicked: For Good.”

“Wicked: For Good” brings fans the long-awaited finale to the film adaptation of the beloved Broadway musical. And a small change at the very, very end may signify a big change from the original story.

Like the musical, the story ends with Glinda (Ariana Grande) and Elphaba (Cynthia Erivo) forced to separate after belting out Act II’s signature song, “For Good.” Glinda, watching shadows through a cracked door, sees Elphaba melt after Dorothy throws a pail of water at her. Glinda escapes on horseback, shrouded in a black cape. (Yes, Glinda was the mysterious figure we saw escaping a castle in the very first scene of the first “Wicked” movie.) She goes on to assume power in Oz as she mourns her best friend’s death.
Only Elphaba isn’t dead. She’s hiding in a trapdoor, waiting for her beloved Fiyero (Jonathan Bailey) to meet her before they leave for the Land Beyond Oz together.
From there, viewers get a bit of a twist before the movie concludes. Here’s what happens.
How ‘Wicked: For Good’ Ends
The stage version of “Wicked” ends with Elphaba and Fiyero leaving Oz, and Glinda stepping into a position of power.
But in “Wicked: For Good,” viewers see what happens to Glinda after she becomes Oz’s leader. First, she officially declares the land welcome to all animals again.

In the final scene, Glinda looks over the Emerald City as Elphaba and Fiyero trek through a desert to leave Oz. Elphaba looks back for a brief moment. Then Elphaba’s book of spells, the Grimmerie, flutters to life before Glinda’s eyes. Elphaba had given the book to Glinda before Elphaba’s encounter with Dorothy.

As established in the first film, the Grimmerie only opens for and can be read by a true witch, something that, as much as she tried —  whether through begging Madame Morrible (Michelle Yeoh) for sorcery lessons or twirling her practice wand — Glinda decidedly was not.
So what does the Grimmerie opening mean?
We asked the team behind “Wicked: For Good” for their takes on the final scene. See what director Jon M. Chu and stars Cynthia Erivo, Jeff Goldblum and Jonathan Bailey had to say.
How ‘Wicked: For Good’ Stars Interpret the Ending
Chu declines to say “exactly what (the ending) is” by his intention.
But he points to all the different interpretations of what the Grimmerie, “a book of knowledge,” could be, relative to both Glinda and Elphaba.

“Whether (Glinda) finally gets to be who she’s meant to be, that she’s not reliant on this image in this mirror,” Chu says. “She didn’t say, ‘I’m going to be good.’ She says, ‘I’m going to try to be good.’
“Just the effort of trying to be who we’re supposed to be opens and unlocks our unlimited possibilities,” he adds.

The spontaneous opening of the Grimmerie could also relate to the film’s theme of pursuing the truth amid propaganda. By the end of the film, Elphaba’s reputation as the Wicked Witch of the West as told in “The Wizard of Oz” is upended by political lies told by the nonmagical Wizard of Oz and, as actor Michelle Yeoh says, the true wicked witch, Madame Morrible. But while viewers know the truth, in the world of the movie, Ozians do not, after Elphaba tells Glinda not to clear her name.
“It could also be, Cynthia could be Jesus giving us, the humans, this Bible and saying, you know the truth, now what are you going to do with it?” Chu says.

“I think it is a challenge to us as the audience, whereas maybe movie one was more of an answer. This is more a question and challenge for us to see how we’re going to tell our story to the next generation,” he adds.
Erivo says Elphaba leaving the Grimmerie behind represents her entrusting it to Glinda.

“I think Elphaba’s powers exist independent of the Grimmerie, and because she has certain powers, she’s able to read the Grimmerie. It’s like she and Grimmerie have an intrinsic relationship, and so the Grimmerie answers to her,” she explains.
“But her leaving it behind and trusting it to Glinda essentially tells the Grimmerie, ‘You’re in new hands, trust this person,’” she adds.
But that doesn’t mean Elphaba’s lost her connection with the book. She says she believes Elphaba in fact can see the Grimmerie opening for Glinda.

“She has visions, so I think she can see what happens, and she can feel it. And it opening means to her that, one, Glinda’s made the right decision, and two, the Grimmerie trusts Glinda now, so everything’s going to be fine,” she says.
But does Glinda know Elphaba is watching over her?
“I think she’s aware that Elphaba has something to do with it (opening), but I don’t think she’s aware that Elphaba’s alive,” Erivo says.

As for Goldblum, who stars as the Wizard of Oz, he is curious what leaving the Grimmerie behind means for Elphaba’s powers. He also wonders: Why couldn’t Elphaba trust Glinda with the knowledge that they survived?

“Why couldn’t she trust that, ‘Hey we’re going to be OK, don’t try to contact us ... Don’t tell anybody that we faked it.’ I don’t know,” Goldblum says. “Or, is the loss that (Glinda) experiences the portal, the thing that triggers her power. Her ability to go through that loss of the greatest love that she’s ever had with Elphaba, does that trigger her ability to power?”
As for the opening of the Grimmerie, Goldblum says it’s possible for Elphaba to “telepathically” “commune” with Glinda across space.
“Does Glinda go, ‘I don’t think I did that. Are you out there somewhere. Are you OK?’” he adds. “Maybe it’s meant to be ambiguous.”
Like Goldblum, Bailey believes there’s a chance the opening of the Grimmerie was Elphaba sending Glinda a message.

“I think that the answers always lie in the Grimmerie, and I do think it’s particularly thrilling to see the Grimmerie come alive for someone ... (with) the absolute knowledge that she has no magic and that she has no power,” he says.
“To see the Grimmerie come alive feels to me like a transference and a conversation between the two women.”
He believes this, even if it’s not so literal of a conversation or message.
“As we know with grief as well, those people do always exist in a different form, don’t they? In a metaphysical sense, they are still living on together,” he adds.
Holzman, who wrote the book for “Wicked” and co-wrote the screenplays for both films with writer Dana Fox, says the goal for the ending was to create a “mystical moment.”
“With something mystical, it’s not like the whole point is you know the answer, it’s that it pulls something out of you, like a spiritual feeling,” she says.
One interpretation of the Grimmerie opening, Holzman says, has to do with the evolution of Glinda’s character.
“She was willing to let go ... of all the need to be admired in this empty way. And she was willing to be humble, to be a student, to say, ‘I don’t know everything,’” Holzman says.
Fox adds that the moment Glinda “earns” the Grimmerie opening is when she admits her “deepest shame” to Elphaba: that she can’t read the Grimmerie and perform spells.

“She wanted so much to be that magical creature who could make magic happen, and she’s going to end up being that, but it’s going to take hard work,” Holzman says. “And to me, the Grimmerie opening is like the Grimmerie saying, ‘OK, you’re ready.’”
But the question remains: Does Elphaba know?

“I think the thing that really is up to interpretation that everyone should just talk about amongst themselves is, Does Elphaba know? Did she have anything to do with it? I think that is something that just everyone should decide for themselves,” Fox says.

title: Who Won Miss Universe 2025? Miss Mexico Crowned After Sparking a Walkout
summary: Fatima Bosch has taken home the title of Miss Universe 2025 just weeks after her tense interaction with a pageant executive went viral
story: Fatima Bosch has taken home the title of Miss Universe 2025 just weeks after her tense interaction with a pageant executive went viral.
Bosch, otherwise known as Miss Mexico, was one of 130 women from around the globe competing at the 74th Miss Universe competition on Nov. 20 in Bangkok, Thailand.

After being crowned Miss Universe 2025, Bosch celebrated her achievements in an Instagram post, writing, “Today I reaffirmed that what God has destined for you, neither envy stops it, nor destiny aborts it, nor luck changes it. Long live Christ the King ❤️ 🔥.”
The official Miss Universe Instagram account shared a similar message, writing, “Because the dreams become reality, and because God willed it that way.”
The 2025 Miss Universe competition has been mired in controversy this season.

In early November, Nawat Itsaragrisil, a Thai businessman and national director of Miss Universe Thailand, berated Bosch for not participating in certain promotional activities for the pageant and its host country. Bosch defended herself to Itsaragrisil. As several contestants began to walk out, Itsaragrisil said those who leave would not be able to compete.
Bosch told the Miami Herald after the event that “no one can shut our voice and no one will do that to me.”
The next day, Itsaragrisil seemed to apologize in an Instagram live video. Miss Universe’s president then dismissed Itsaragrisil from participating in this year’s pageant.

In addition, two Miss Universe judges resigned earlier this week, just before the pageant, with one threatening a lawsuit and accusing organizers of rigging, and Miss Jamaica suffered a fall onstage in a preliminary event on Nov. 19.
Controversy aside, leaders and Miss Universe participants rallied around Bosch as she was crowned.

“We women look more beautiful when we raise our voice and participate, because that has to do with the recognition of our rights,” Mexican President Claudia Sheinbaum said at a news conference following the pageant.

title: Why Ed Sheeran Was Interviewed Live in a Taxi on TODAY
summary: Ed Sheeran sat down with TODAY in a taxi to discuss his new Netflix special, "One Shot with Ed Sheeran,” which follows him around New York City in one  shot.
story: We cab hardly believe Ed Sheeran’s latest interview.

The four-time Grammy-winning singer-songwriter sat down with Craig Melvin in a taxi for a live TODAY interview Nov. 21. It was all in support of his new Netflix special, “One Shot with Ed Sheeran,” which captures the superstar in one single continuous shot in New York City, as he performs, surprises fans and strangers along the way.
Why did the interview take place in a taxi? It’s a cheeky tip of the cap to “One Shot,” which features Sheeran using multiple modes of transportation while traveling around the Big Apple.

“One Shot with Ed Sheeran” is directed by Philip Barantini, who won an Emmy Award for helming Netflix’s critically acclaimed “Adolescence.” Each episode of that series was also done in one single shot. Sheeran, who says the special is all live in one take over the course of one hour, says this was an opportunity to do something different.
“I got approached to do a concert special and the idea was just do it in a theater. And I was like, ‘Seems boring. It seems like it’s been done before,’” he said.

“I just watched ‘Adolescence’ on Netflix, which was, each episode was one continuous shot. It’s amazing how they do it. It’s connected to drones, putting in cars, everything like that. We got in touch with Phil Barantini, who made ‘Adolescence,’ asked him if he wants to do it. He was up for it.”
The singer says managing to record his adventures in New York City was no easy task.

“I mean, New York is a chaotic city to do it in ‘cause we did it in rush hour as well, so we go from the venue to the taxi to the High Line to the bus to the top of a hotel, then they drive you down and I’m in an Irish bar,” he said. “Then I’m in a car. Then I go underneath in a subway and then I end up at the venue. But it’s all one camera.”
Sheeran, who once performed in someone’s living room, may be a global superstar, but even he marvels at how “One Shot” turned out.
“I think, by far, it’s the best thing I’ve been involved with in my career,” he said.
“I’m super, super proud of it,” he added. “It was an insane experience. I’ve never done anything like that.”
“One Shot with Ed Sheeran” is available to stream now on Netflix.
Sheeran will hit more than just the Big Apple when his “Loop Tour” treks across North America next year, beginning June 13 in Glendale, Arizona, and wrapping up Nov. 7 in Tampa, Florida.

title: EXCLUSIVE: Cynthia Erivo Says The Part That’ll Make You Cry in ‘Wicked: For Good’ Wasn’t In the Script
summary: Cynthia Erivo reveals to TODAY.com that she and Ariana Grande performed "For Good" with plenty of lines that weren't originally written in the script.
story: Warning: This story contains spoilers for "Wicked: For Good."
One of the most emotional moments in "Wicked: For Good" wasn't just between Elphaba and Glinda, but also between Cynthia Erivo and Ariana Grande.

"Wicked: For Good," the long-awaited sequel to 2024's "Wicked," picks up a year after the events of the first film. Erivo's Elphaba has embraced her reputation as a "Wicked Witch," while her best friend Glinda — played by Grande — has taken up the mantle of the "Good Witch," serving as a figurehead to lift Ozians' spirits.

Unlike the first film, Elphaba and Glinda spend much of the film apart. They briefly reunite before Glinda and Fiyero's wedding, then again at the very end, when Glinda goes to warn Elphaba of an incoming march of witch hunters.
It's during that final scene that Erivo and Grande perform the film's titular song, "For Good." Director Jon M. Chu says that scene was the one he most nervous for.

"That’s such an iconic song. We’ve seen so many covers, so many people do those songs. It’s the end of a two-movie series. How do you make it grand? Or feel like it earns the last song of the movie? But at the end of the day, these two women earned the right to drive the car during that," he tells TODAY.com.
Erivo says she and Grande did that indeed, beginning to make the song their own during in rehearsals.
"We'd sort of run through what it could be, and then right after the song where it would end, we just kept going, and (Chu) just didn't stop us," she tells TODAY.com.
In the film, "For Good" transitions into a hurried and heartbreaking goodbye between the best friends as the witch hunters, led by the Tin Man, descend on Elphaba's hideout.
After the song, Elphaba tells Glinda she has to go now, and she responds, "What's going on?"
"That wasn't scripted," Erivo says. "I said, 'Don't worry, everything's going to be fine' — not scripted."
Elphaba hurries Glinda away and finds a closet for her to hide in. Before it closes, they each say "I love you." That, too, came about from Erivo and Grande's improvisation.
"The moment that I tell her I love her at the door, and she says it back, that was not in the script. That was something that we — that happened," she says.
"All of that was sort of what she and I found in the room," Erivo adds.
Chu specifically "just let us find it," she says. "We found out how we could say goodbye." Goodbye not only as their characters, but to their characters.

"I think both of us were just figuring out how each of our characters would actually say goodbye," she says. "Even through the song, there wasn't much direction. He just let us sing to one another. Tell each other the truth."

title: Jelly Roll Looks Unrecognizable After Shaving His Face
summary: Jelly Roll has debuted a new look that even shocked himself while reacting to a recent milestone moment: receiving three nominations at the upcoming 2026 Grammys.
story: Jelly Roll has debuted a new look that even shocked himself while reacting to a recent milestone moment: receiving three nominations at the upcoming 2026 Grammys.

On Nov. 20, the 40-year-old musician uploaded a vlog to YouTube, marking his “long overdue” comeback to the video style that he used during the early days of his career. The 15-minute clip began with footage of him on his Nashville farm and ended with Jelly Roll deciding to shave his beard for the first time in over a decade.
He shared that he wanted to shave his beard as he continues his weight loss journey.

“At this point, I’m sure some of y’all are exhausted about hearing about my weight loss. But a lot of things change when you start losing weight. You realize things. One of the things I realized is I don’t know what I look like. I’ve had a beard to try to cover up my double chin,” he said.
Jelly Roll added, “The last time my face was shaved I was fresh out of jail.”

He predicted that he might resemble a Ninja Turtle after shaving his facial hair, but said he wanted to go through with it so he could surprise his family with his new appearance. He shared that he only told his wife, Bunnie XO, about his plans to shave his beard and that his daughter, Bailee Ann, had never seen him without it.

The “Get By” singer used timelapse editing to show him slowly removing his beard as his wife looked on and filmed the moment on her phone. About halfway through the process, he turned to Bunnie XO, who appeared stunned.
“Oh my gosh,” she said as he laughed. She later gave her stamp of approval when he finished, telling her husband, “I love it.”

He blurred out his face in the shot, saving the reveal for the last minutes of the video. Before he debuted his look to his fans, he showed off his clean-shaven face to his daughter, who instantly responded with laughter.
“Stay over there!” she playfully told her dad. “Oh my gosh, I’m going to cry. I don’t like this! You look like a turtle.”
Without further ado, Jelly Roll finally turned the camera toward himself for the grand reveal.
“By now, you have probably figured out that I look like a Ninja Turtle,” he joked while strolling through a wooded area. “Yeah, this was crazy.”
Taking a more sentimental tone, he continued, “You know, one of the reasons I’d even started growing a beard was because I was so obese, it was just easier to cover up what was happening here.”

He then went on to talk about “the craziest thing” that has ever happened to him: his latest Grammy nominations. When the Recording Academy announced the list of nominees for the 2026 Grammys on Nov. 6, Jelly Roll was one of the many stars who received the coveted recognition. He was nominated for best contemporary country album for “Beautifully Broken,” best country duo/group performance for his collaboration with Shaboozey called “Amen” and best contemporary Christian music performance/song for “Hard Fought Hallelujah.”

In his vlog, Jelly Roll recalled receiving his first Grammy nomination at the 66th Annual Grammy Awards in 2024 for best new artist. He said that at the time he never imagined he would be recognized by the Recording Academy again.

“I don’t care what artists say. I don’t care what artists act like. I’m going to tell you the real truth. There’s not an artist in the world that didn’t grow up watching the Grammys when they were a kid and walk in their bedrooms afterwards and rehearse their speech,” he said. “God will take something that’s either normal and make it extremely abnormal or he will take something that’s already incredible and make it absolutely mesmerizing, and that’s the case here.”
He said that now he gets to celebrate this achievement while in “the best headspace.”

“I see all my friends in this category. But then I just see standing there is this album called ‘Beautifully Broken,’” he added. “Man, if that doesn’t represent what’s happening in the world right now. I think more than ever… I think we can find beauty in what’s happening. Win, lose or draw. Holy f---, dude, we won.”
He expressed his gratitude again to the Record Academy and said he wouldn’t have accomplished anything without his faith.
Before signing off, he encouraged his fans to mock his beardless face.
“I thought my chin went at least a half inch further than it actually went, f---. I didn’t know. Failed science experiment, y’all!” he said.
Jelly Roll uploaded the snippet of his newly shaven face to Instagram, too. Celebrity friends complimented him about his Grammy nominations beneath the post.
Charlie Puth said, “Very inspiring man.”
Country singer Carly Pearce echoed that sentiment, calling Jelly Roll “an inspiration.”
Meanwhile, fans gave their approval of his look.
“Fresh fit and clean faced,” one fan commented.
Another said, “Shut up I love it!!! You look so good!!!!!”
“Hey i love ninja turtles,” a third wrote.
This is the latest dramatic transformation Jelly Roll has shared with his fans. Over the past year, he has also opened up repeatedly about losing weight.
While appearing on “Jimmy Kimmel Live!” in April, he said his goal was to be under 250 pounds before explaining why losing weight is important to him.

“To do all the fun stuff in life, you’ve gotta be under 250,” he told host Jimmy Kimmel before mentioning skydiving, riding a rollercoaster, riding a bull and wrestling an alligator. “I’ve got a list of things I want to do.”
He gave a progress update in August while giving a speech to the Tennessee Titans. “I lost 200 pounds,” he said. “I told coach I’m getting a contract if I lose another 50.”

title: Which ‘Married at First Sight’ Season 19 Couples Are Still Together Now?
summary: After eight weeks of marriage, the cast of "Married at First Sight" reached the end of their romantic experiment in the Season 19 finale.
story: After eight weeks of marriage, the cast of "Married at First Sight" reached the end of their romantic experiment in the Season 19 finale.
During the action-packed episode, the five couples were tasked with deciding whether to stay married to the person they met for the first time at the altar — or go their separate ways.
Following the finale, the entire Season 19 cast got together for a reunion special to share the current status of their relationships since filming wrapped a year and a half ago.
Who ended up together and who got divorced? Here's a full recap.
Jalyn and Josh

How it started: After getting married at first sight, Jalyn and Josh quickly reached a level of comfort with each other. They embarked on the experiment alongside Jalyn's mother, Belynda, who married Chad at first sight.

How it went: Over the course of eight weeks, the newlyweds encountered several highs and lows. They experienced trust issues when Josh claimed that he had unfollowed his ex-girlfriend on social media, but later revealed that he hadn't.

The couple learned that they had a few key personality differences when Josh expressed how passionate he was about attending music festivals, namely Burning Man. Jalyn didn't share the same interest and wasn't sure that she'd feel comfortable attending the event. Josh was concerned that he would lose the sense of community he finds at Burning Man if his wife didn't support his passion.
How it ended in the season finale: Going into decision day, Josh was feeling “extremely thankful” about his experience with Jalyn.
“We’ve definitely had our ups and downs but I think we’ve had far more ups and the downs have always brought us closer,” he said.
Josh acknowledged that he envisioned "a great future" with his wife and said decision day would "take a part of me with it" if Jalyn decided against continuing their marriage.
Meanwhile, Jalyn opened up about her "biggest reservations" as she prepared for decision day, saying she and Josh are "different people" who are "in two different lanes in a lot of ways."

"I feel like this is make or break for me. I think in the past anytime I saw a red flag, I ended the relationship but now I'm married and I don't know what you work through and what you don't. But I hope to feel confident and secure in my decision," she said.
When decision time arrived, Both Jalyn and Josh decided to stay married and expressed confidence in the way they had addressed obstacles in their relationship so far.

Are they still together? No. During the reunion special, Jalyn revealed that she and Josh broke up three months before filming the reunion. They both had different versions of their breakup story, with Jalyn saying Josh broached the subject while they were on vacation.
"He looked at me and he said, 'I don't feel connected to you anymore. I want to break up,'" she recalled.
After agreeing to try to work things out, they went home and a few days later, Josh initiated the breakup again.

Jalyn said she bent over backwards to channel her adventurous side and did attend Burning Man, along with several other music festivals, for Josh. In the end, however, he said she wasn't adventurous enough for him.
Jalyn also claimed that Josh "lied" about many things in their relationship, such as telling her a female coworker was younger than he originally stated.
Meghann and Derrek
How it started: When Meghann and Derrek got married, the physical attraction was immediately present. The newlyweds shared a passion for healthy living and seemed to have a lot in common.

How it went: Meghann and Derrek encountered a few issues throughout the experiment. For instance, Derrek thought Meghann was too defensive in their conversations, and she wanted him to be more vulnerable. They also had misaligned expectations on their household roles and duties.
When Meghann discovered that she was pregnant, their relationship shifted for the better, with both of the newlyweds committing to their connection.
How it ended in the season finale: On decision day, Derrek noted that Meghann's pregnancy added "a whole other element" to the experiment. Still, he was feeling confident going into the discussion.

On her way to filming, Meghann reflected on the moment, saying, "We have a lot of things that are gonna hit us, a lot of new things in the future that we're gonna have to figure out. And we need to really work through this."
While sitting down with the relationship experts, the couple announced their pregnancy. When the big moment arrived, Derrek went first and shared his decision.

"You are extremely caring and compassionate and without any hesitation, 100% I want to stay married to you. I love you and I love your sense of humor. I love your pretty smile and your big blue eyes and I am really excited to start a family with you. I think you'll make an amazing mom and I'm just really excited for our future," he said.
Meghann told her husband he makes her "a better person" and expressed her devotion to him.
"I am so excited to raise a child with you, so I am choosing to stay married to you because I can't imagine being away from you and I love you," she said.

Are they still together? No. After agreeing to stay together in the season finale, the couple experienced a miscarriage. Despite Meghann's suggestion that they go to couples' therapy, they still struggled to communicate. One day, they had a fight and Derrek broke up with his wife over the phone then moved out.
"There's never a good time to do it. It's always going to be hard. I knew that this wasn't the right person for me. I had to be true to myself and be true to Meghann," Derrek said.

Meghann offered her take on the breakup, saying, "When he broke up with me, something in my head changed and I couldn't remember anything good from our relationship. I just remembered all the bad. And then I watched (the show) and then I remembered all the good and that was hard."
Meghann said she doesn't see Derrek as a "bad person," but said he didn't handle their breakup well.
"I wasn't happy. I don't think Meghann was happy," he said.
Rhonda and Pat

How it started: It didn't take long for chemistry to spark between Rhonda and Pat on their wedding day. The couple had plenty of fun at their reception and even jumped in the pool together. It was soon apparent that their fun-loving personalities were a good match.

How it went: Once they started diving deeper in their relationship, Rhonda and Pat hit a few roadblocks. Rhonda told her husband she didn't feel like he was interested in hearing about her life since he regularly made the conversation about him. He was taken aback and tried to remedy the situation.
Still, it was a consistent theme throughout the eight-week experiment for the newlyweds.
How it ended in the season finale: While preparing to make his decision Pat admitted that he was feeling "conflicted."
"Despite the disconnects and the challenges that Rhonda and I have had, we did make a deep connection. And I feel in my heart that I have established deep love for Rhonda," he said.
While reflecting on the decision awaiting her, Rhonda said she wanted Pat to know that she "really sincerely appreciated him and his commitment to this marriage."
"It's been hard but also it's been everything I think I could have ever hoped for," she said.

When it came time to share their decisions, Rhonda said she suspected that Pat didn't want to stay married based on his closed off body language. He then explained that he ignored red flags in his first marriage and didn't want to do that this time around.
"I do not trust that I will be seen and heard as my authentic self," he said.
Rhonda wasn't sure what he meant, so Pat explained that he had struggled hearing her repeatedly allege he didn't care about her.
The relationship experts on hand encouraged the couple to talk through their issues. Rhonda apologized to Pat but said her emotional needs hadn't been met.

"I just think I've been really, really frustrated with you and my frustration pushes you away. And that's not my intention. I'm struggling on how to deal with it. So I would (like to) apologize for making you feel like I'm pushing you away," she said.
Pat thanked his wife and said he went into the discussion not wanting to move forward, but was now thinking he may be "being too rigid."

Ultimately, Pat decided he wanted to continue to work on their marriage. Rhonda said she didn't feel "as open or hopeful" as she did going into the discussion, but wasn't ready to give up on their relationship.

Are they still together? No. During the reunion, Rhonda said she and Pat stayed together for nine months after decision day. At that point, Pat went to Europe for a month on his own. He did invite her to go, but she'd already taken a lot of time off from work and decided to stay home.

When Pat returned home, Rhonda said she was "on cloud nine" for a period of 10 days. One day, she saw him listening to a meditation about anger and asked if he was angry that they hadn't slept together since he got home. He was, and at dinner that night he told Rhonda he was done with their relationship.
During the reunion, Pat said he'd felt that way "for quite some time." Rhonda then explained that he was "very insecure" and said "that insecurity was a complete turnoff romantically."

Rhonda suggested that Pat only wanted a wife, and not necessarily her, adding that he wanted physical intimacy that would turn into a romantic connection. However, she wanted a connection and said intimacy would be the icing on the cake.
Belynda and Chad

How it started: When Belynda and Chad got married, it was a slow burn at first. However, they both seemed committed to exploring their connection and shared some sweet moments as they got to know each other.

How it went: Chad repeatedly expressed frustration with Belynda's dog sleeping in their bed throughout the experiment. He also grew tired of the filming schedule and said "I don't give a f--- about this show" during one heated moment. Still, the couple's connection grew over time.
Before decision day, Belynda said she was doubtful that she'd want to stay married based on Chad's recent aggressive behavior.
How it ended in the season finale: Belynda described her husband as "kind, funny and sweet" on decision day but admitted that her marriage had been "a little exhausting at times."
“I just don’t want to lose my voice. I can’t lose myself in a marriage and I feel like I need to remember that I’m also there and that I also matter,” she said.
In a confessional interview, Chad said he wanted to be with his wife and couldn't "imagine my life without Belynda."
He also acknowledged that he had "hurt" his wife at times with his impatience and said he needed "to find healthier ways to burn off some steam."
